questions.question: Match the following terms with their correct definitions: 1. Subclinical case a. The first case of a disease identified in a group or population 2. Primary case b. A person who contracts the disease directly from the primary case. 3. Secondary case c. A person who exhibits mild or no symptoms but is still infected 4. Index case d. The first case that comes to the attention of health authorities
questions.explanation: show any apparent symptoms. However, they can still transmit the disease to others. This is important in epidemiology because these cases can silently spread infections. Primary case: It is the first case of a disease identified in a group or population. This case introduces the disease to a previously unaffected population and is often the source of an outbreak. Secondary case: It results from direct contact with a primary case. These individuals contract the disease from the primary case, representing the spread of the infection within the population. Index case: It is the first case that health authorities have noticed. It's important to note that the index case is not always the same as the primary case. Sometimes, health authorities might identify a case that turns out to have been infected by an earlier, previously undetected case. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 103

questions.question: A 6-year-old child visits the pediatric clinic with a high fever, cough, runny nose, and conjunctivitis. Three days later, the child develops a distinctive maculopapular rash that begins on the face and spreads to the rest of the body. The oral pharyngeal examination is shown below. During what period is this child most likely contagious and should be isolated to prevent transmission to others?

options.A: 1-2 days before to 4-5 days after the appearance of rash
options.B: 4-6 days before symptoms to 7 days thereafter
options.C: From 4 days before to 4 days after rash onset.
options.D: 7 days before symptoms to 7 days after the appearance of the r

questions.explanation: communicability is when an infectious agent can be transferred directly or indirectly from an infected person to others, from infected animals to humans, or from infected individuals to animals or arthropods. Period of communicability of different diseases: Disease Period of communicability Measles 4 days before to 4 days after

questions.question: A 5-year-old child presents to the community health centre with a fever, malaise, and an itchy, vesicular rash (shown in the image below) that began two days ago. The child's mother asks when it will be safe for her child to return to school without posing a risk of spreading the infection to other children. What is the appropriate advice regarding the duration of isolation for this child to prevent the spread of this infection?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Until all lesions are crusted Explanation: The given scenario and rash in the image depict Chickenpox caused by the varicella-zoster virus. It is highly contagious and primarily spreads

questions.question: Match the following diseases with their typical incubation periods: 1. COVID-19
questions.explanation: the first symptom. During the incubation period, the infectious agent multiplies within the host. Once the agent reaches a sufficient density, it disrupts the host's health equilibrium, leading to overt disease. The median incubation period is when 50% of cases occur following exposure. Factors determining the incubation period: The generation time of the pathogen Infective dose Portal of entry Individual susceptibility The incubation period of different diseases: Diseases Incubation period COVID-19 3-21 days Typhoid 10-14 days Influenza 18-72 hours Measles 10-14 days Mumps 14-21 days Rubella 2-3 weeks Varicella 14-16 days Hepatitis A 15 to 50 days Hepatitis B 30 to 180 days Hepatitis C 14 to 180 days Hepatitis E 15 to 60 days

questions.question: During an outbreak of measles in a small community, a primary case was identified in a household of 6 people. Within the next two weeks, 4 additional household members developed measles. What is the secondary attack rate (SAR) for this household?
questions.explanation: case. To calculate the Secondary Attack Rate (SAR): Number of new cases (secondary cases) = 4 Number of susceptible people initially exposed = 5 (since the primary case is not considered susceptible) SAR = (4 / 5) × 100 = 80% Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 108

questions.question: What specific measure does the term "secondary attack rate" refer to?

options.C: Number of deaths due to a disease.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 80% Explanation: The secondary attack rate measures the communicability of a disease. Definition: "The number of exposed persons developing the disease within the incubation period range, following exposure to the primary case." Formula: Advantages: Can compare attack rates in vaccinated vs. unvaccinated groups. Created to measure the communicability of an infection within families or closed groups. Limitations: It is less effective for diseases with long infective periods (e.g., tuberculosis) where exposure duration impacts spread. Using history, it is easier to measure diseases like measles and chickenpox but harder to measure diseases like influenza. All exposed family members must be included when susceptibles are hard to identify. Limited usefulness in diseases with many subclinical cases; requires lab confirmation. The Burden of the disease (Option A) measures the Proportional mortality rate, not a secondary attack rate. The number of deaths due to a disease (Option C): measures the Case fatality rate. Carrier status of a disease (Option D): The Secondary attack rate does not measure the carrier status of a disease. The Secondary attack rate does not measure the carrier status of a disease.

questions.question: During a local polio outbreak, a routine health check reveals poliovirus in the stool of a 10-year-old boy who shows no symptoms of illness. He has been participating in community sports events. What type of carrier is this boy most likely to be?
questions.explanation: transmit it through faecal-oral routes. These carriers play a significant role in spreading the virus by shedding it in their stool. While convalescent carriers can occur with polio, they are less commonly associated with the transmission than healthy carriers. Types of Carrier Definition Examples Healthy (Asymptomatic) Harbours and transmits a pathogen without showing symptoms. Polio Typhoid fever COVID-19 Meningitis Cholera Incubatory (Option C ruled out) Can transmit the disease during the incubation period before symptoms appear. Measles Influenza Pertussis Polio Mumps Convalescent (Option A ruled out) Continues to harbour and shed the pathogen for a short period after recovering from acute illness. Diphtheria Meningococcal meningitis Typhoid Cholera Chronic (Option D ruled out) Harbours and excretes the pathogen for an extended period (often >1 year) after initial infection. Hepatitis B Typhoid fever Malaria Gonorrhoea Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 103-104

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the median incubation period?

options.A: Shortest time from exposure to symptom onset in 50% of cases
options.B: Longest time from exposure to symptom onset in 50% of cases
options.C: Average time from exposure to recovery in 50% of cases
options.D: Average time from exposure to symptom onset in 50% of cases

questions.explanation: incubation period is the time between infection and the first symptom appearance. During incubation, the pathogen multiplies until it reaches a threshold to cause symptoms. Most diseases aren't communicable during incubation, except for measles and chickenpox. Incubation periods vary by disease and individual, ranging from hours to years. Examples: Short (hours to days): Food poisoning, cholera. Medium (10 days to 3 weeks): Typhoid, COVID-19, measles. Long (weeks to years): Hepatitis, Rabies, leprosy. Non-infectious diseases like cancer also have incubation periods, often lasting months or years. Shortest time from exposure to symptom onset in 50% of cases (Option A) describes the minimum incubation period, not the median. Longest time from exposure to symptom onset in 50% of cases (Option B) describes the maximum incubation period, not the median. Average time from exposure to recovery in 50% of cases (Option C) describes the average recovery time, not the incubation period. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 107

questions.question: Match the following terms with their correct definitions: 1.Serial Interval a. The time from infection to the onset of symptoms. 2.Incubation Period b. The time between the onset of symptoms in a primary case and the onset of symptoms in secondary cases. 3.Window Period c. The time between infection and when the pathogen can be detected by laboratory tests. 4.Generation Time d. The time from infection in a new host to the onset of symptoms in that new host.
questions.explanation: infected in a chain of transmission) and the onset of symptoms in secondary cases (people infected by the primary case). It helps epidemiologists understand how quickly a disease spreads from one person to another within a community or population. Incubation Period: The incubation period refers to the time it takes for an individual to develop symptoms after being infected with a pathogen. It begins with exposure to the pathogen and ends with the appearance of recognisable symptoms. Window Period: The window period is the time between infection and when the infection can be reliably detected by diagnostic tests. The individual may be infectious during this period, but tests might not yet show positive results. This concept is important in screening and testing strategies for infectious diseases. Generation Time: Generation time refers to the time the newly infected person takes to show symptoms. It encompasses the entire cycle of infection, transmission, and symptom onset in the context of disease spread. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 107-108

questions.question: Which of the following statements best describes the difference between a carrier state and a latency period? transmissible appear. symptoms have resolved

options.A: Carrier state: Symptomatic Latency period: Asymptomatic
options.B: Carrier state: Pathogen transmissible, even asymptomatic. Latency period: Pathogen dormant, not
options.C: Carrier state: Time before initial exposure to the pathogen Latency period: Time before symptoms
options.D: Carrier state: Occurs when the person is recovering from the disease. Latency period: Occurs after

questions.explanation: Pathogen dormant, not transmissible pathogen is actively transmissible even if the person shows no symptoms. Aspects Carrier State Latency Period Pathogen Activity The pathogen is present and active. The pathogen is present but dormant. Symptoms No symptoms were shown by the person. Transmissibility The pathogen is transmissible to others. Pathogen is not transmissible. Stage in Disease Course It can occur after recovery or without any disease phase. Typically, it occurs between the initial infection and the onset of symptoms. Detection Pathogens can be detected through tests. Pathogens may not be easily detectable. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 103

questions.question: Match the appropriate answer: 1) Virulence a) Ability of the pathogen to cause disease by producing toxins and evading host defenses 2) Infectivity b) Ability of the pathogen to enter, survive, and multiply in the host 3) Pathogenicity c) Ability of the pathogen to induce an immune response in the host 4) Antigenicity d) Ability of the pathogen to cause disease by invading tissues and producing toxins
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 1-a, 2-b, 3-d, 4-c Explanation: Virulence It refers to the killing power or severity of the disease. It is the ability of a microorganism to cause severe disease by producing toxins and evading the host's immune defences. It indicates how damaging or harmful the microorganism can be to the host. It doesn’t depend on the disease duration. Infectivity The ability of the pathogen to enter, survive, and multiply in the host. A highly infective pathogen can spread easily and establish an infection. Pathogenicity The ability of the pathogen to cause disease. It involves the pathogen's capacity to invade host tissues and produce toxins or other factors that lead to disease signs and symptoms. Antigenicity The ability of the pathogen to induce an immune response in the host. Pathogens with high antigenicity can be recognized and targeted by the host's immune system, which can affect the severity and duration of the infection. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 100

questions.question: The transfer of infectious agents within the vector from one stage of life to the next occurs in which type of transmission?
questions.explanation: infectious agents within the vector from one stage of life to another. Transovarian transmission (Vertical) Transstadial transmission (Horizontal ) Definition Transfer of infectious agent from the mother vector to its progeny. Transfer of infectious agent within the vector from one stage of life to another. Examples E.g., Kyasanur forest disease, scrub typhus, Q fever, and Rocky Mountain spotted fever. E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi (Lyme disease) Larve gets infected, which develops into a nymph and, lastly, an infected adult. Propagative (Option B) and Cyclopropagative (Option C) transmission are types of biological transmission in which the multiplication of infectious agents occurs within the vector.

questions.question: A 38-year-old male has had a fever of 103°F, chills, and severe headaches that have persisted for three days. A blood smear confirms the presence of Plasmodium falciparum trophozoites in erythrocytes. Which type of biological transmission does this parasite undergo within the vector?
questions.explanation: mosquito. Cyclopropagative transmission in a biological vector refers to the multiplication and development of the agents into their infective form within the vector. Types of biological transmission: Propagative transmission The agent only multiplies in number within the vector. E.g., Yersinia pestis in rat flea. Cyclodevelopmental transmission Agent develops into infective form within the vector without multiplying. E.g.,Microfilaria in culex mosquito Cyclopropagative transmission Agent develops into infective form and multiplies in number within the vector. E.g., Malarial parasite in Anopheles mosquito Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 106

questions.question: Which of the following diseases is spread via droplet nuclei?
questions.explanation: nuclei Direct mode of transmission Indirect mode of transmission It can spread via contact with the oromucosal membrane, conjunctiva. Enters the alveoli. Heavier particles that are more than 5 microns in size Lighter particles which are less than 5 microns in size They fall on the ground due to gravity They remain suspended in the air, and it can disseminate along with air currents Can travel less than 1 meter in distance (Up to 30-60 cm) Can travel more than 1 meter in distance Examples: Common cold (Option C) Diphtheria (Option B) Whooping cough (Option A) Tuberculosis COVID-19 Meningococcal meningitis Examples: Tuberculosis Influenza Chickenpox Measles Q fever COVID-19 Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 105-106

questions.question: A 28-year-old pregnant woman was screened for TORCH infections in her third trimester. Which of the following diseases is typically associated with vertical transmission during this trimester of pregnancy?
questions.explanation: trimester of pregnancy. Vertical transmission refers to the transplacental transmission of infectious agents from the mother to the fetus. TORCH infections include toxoplasmosis, rubella, CMV, Herpes and HIV. Vertical transmission of diseases. 1st trimester Rubella, Chickenpox/varicella 2nd trimester Parvovirus 3rd trimester Toxoplasmosis, CMV, Hepatitis B and Syphilis. During delivery HIV and herpes Other agents that are non-living can also be transferred vertically: Thalidomide Diethylstilbestrol Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 105

questions.question: A 37-year-old male presents with sudden onset fever and a rapidly enlarging tender lymph node in the left axilla. Considering the clinical history of plague, which of the following is not true regarding the vector responsible for transmission of this infection?

options.B: Pathogen undergoes development within the vector.

questions.explanation: bacilli undergo multiplication (Propagative transmission). Mechanical vector Biological vector Infectious agent is mechanically transported on the feet or proboscis of the agent. (Option A) It can also get passively excreted unchanged from the agent GIT. (Option D) Infectious agents are taken up by the vector, where they can undergo a necessary development cycle. (Option B) An agent does not undergo multiplication or development within the vector. E.g., the spread of bacillary dysentery by houseflies. Agent undergoes Multiplication (propagative) - plague bacilli in fleas. Development (cyclo-developmental) - microfilariae in culex mosquito. Both (cyclo-propagative) - malaria parasites in Anopheles. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 105-106

questions.question: Which of the following diseases exclusively involves obligate hosts in its transmission cycle?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Measles Explanation: Obligate hosts are the only hosts that are necessary for the completion of a pathogen's life cycle. Person-to-person transmission is present. E.g., Typhoid, Measles Sleeping sickness (Option B): Sleeping sickness (African trypanosomiasis) involves multiple hosts in its transmission cycle, not just obligate hosts. The cycle includes: Tsetse flies (vector) Humans (Main host for Trypanosoma brucei gambiense) Wild and domestic animals (Reservoir hosts for Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense). This complex cycle involves both obligate and non-obligate hosts. Hydatid disease (Option C): Hydatid disease is caused by the tapeworm Echinococcus. Definitive hosts: dogs and other canines Intermediate hosts: sheep, cattle, humans This cycle doesn't rely solely on obligate hosts. Filaria (Option D): Filariasis is caused by filarial worms (e.g., Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi). It involves multiple hosts in its transmission cycle: Mosquitoes (vector), Humans (main host) Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 101

questions.question: Which of the following diseases are seen in the transmission cycle of dead-end hosts?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Tetanus Explanation: Dead-end hosts are hosts in which the infectious agent cannot be transmitted from one human to another susceptible human. Tetanus : Clostridium tetani, the causative agent, does not spread from person to person. Infection occurs through wound contamination with spores found in soil or animal faeces. Other examples are Japanese encephalitis, Rabies, and Plague. Tuberculosis (Option B) is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis . It is transmitted from person to person through airborne droplets. As humans are the primary and continuous hosts, it does not involve dead-end hosts in its transmission cycle. Dengue fever (Option C) primarily involves Aedes mosquitoes as vectors. Humans are incidental hosts, not dead-end hosts, as they can transmit the virus back to mosquitoes. Malaria (Option D) involves a complex transmission cycle with Anopheles mosquitoes as vectors. Humans are necessary hosts for the parasite's life cycle to complete, not dead-end hosts. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 101

questions.question: Which of the following correctly identifies the primary and secondary hosts?

options.A: Malaria: Primary Host - Mosquitoes, Secondary Host - Humans
options.B: Filaria: Primary Host - Humans, Secondary Host - Mosquitoes(Anopheles)
options.C: Dengue: Primary Host - Ticks, Secondary Host - Humans
options.D: Chikungunya: Primary Host - Humans, Secondary Host - Ticks

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Malaria: Primary host - Mosquitoes; Secondary Host - Humans Explanation: Primary Host Secondary Host Definition The organism in which the parasite reaches maturity. Agent reproduces sexually in the primary host. The organism in which the parasite lives for a shorter period, often as an intermediate stage. There is no sexual maturation of the agent in the secondary agent. Examples Malaria Mosquitoes (Anopheles species) Humans Filaria Humans Mosquitoes Dengue Mosquitoes (Aedes species) Humans Chikungunya Humans Mosquitoes (Aedes species) Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 101

questions.question: Which of the following correctly pairs the disease with its primary reservoir and source of infection?

options.A: Disease: Measles, Reservoir: Humans, Source of Infection: Respiratory droplets
options.B: Disease: Plague, Reservoir: Soil, Source of Infection: Contaminated wounds
options.C: Disease: Tetanus, Reservoir: Humans, Source of Infection: Mosquito bites
options.D: Disease: Malaria, Reservoir: Wild rodents, Source of Infection: Flea bites

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Measles: Reservoir - Humans; Source - Respiratory droplets Explanation: Disease Reservoir Source of Infection TB Humans Respiratory droplets. HIV Blood, sexual contact, mother-to-child. Typhoid Contaminated food and water. Measles (Option A) Respiratory droplets. Malaria (Option D) Mosquito bites (Anopheles species). Cholera Contaminated water and food. KFD (Kyasanur Forest Disease) Small mammals, monkeys Tick bites. Tetanus (Option C) Soil Plague (Option B) Wild rodents (e.g., rats) Flea bites. JE (Japanese Encephalitis) Pigs, wild birds Mosquito bites (Culex species). Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 102
